Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Effects of Warming and Clipping on Coupling of Carbon and Water Cycles in a Tallgrass Prairie
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecosystems are providing critical ecological services to the human society. The services are likely to be strongly affected by climate change and biofuel production, but these effects have not been carefully studied over long time periods. The primary goal of this project is to assess long-term impacts of climate warming and biomass harvest on ecosystem services related to biofuel feedstock production, carbon sequestration, and water cycling, and biodiversity. The project will continue a long-term warming and biomass harvest experiment, which has been conducted in the southern Great Plains, USA, since November 1999. The investigators will quantify biomass production; soil carbon sequestration; partitioning of precipitation to evaporation, transpiration, and runoff; water use efficiency for plant biomass growth; length of growing seasons, and plant biodiversity in response to climate warming and biomass harvest.

Results from this study on changes in runoff, freshwater supply, soil fertility, biofuel feedstock production, carbon sequestration, regulation of climate change by ecosystems, and biodiversity in response to climate warming and biomass harvest are highly relevant to the well-being of society and have implications for diverse environmental policies. This project also trains the next generation of scientists and will improve K-12 and university education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our understanding on long-term responses of ecosystems to climate change and land use change is limited due to the insufficient evidence from long-term experiments. The manipulated experiment in this project allowed us to look into the long-term ecosystem responses to climate change (warming) and land use practice (clipping), which is impossible to be detected in the short-term experiments, in particular for some slow but critical ecosystem processes that may regulate the feedback between ecosystem functions and warming or biomass harvesting, such as change in soil carbon and species composition. Among many other important findings on the responses of ecosystem processes to warming and clipping, the most interesting finding is that the ecosystem has been shifted to another state after a certain years of treatments. During the first seven years of treatments, plant community structure, net primary productivity (NPP), and soil respiration did respond to warming and clipping, but the ecosystem was resistant to these disturbances. However, from the eighth year all the way down to the thirteenth or fourteenth year, more striking divergence occurred in relative abundance of dominant species, NPP and soil respiration between treatments, indicating the system has changed to another state. The state change might be trigged by species invasion or interaction between experimental warming and climate extremes, such as drought or extreme wetness that the ecosystem had undergone around the seventh year. These findings will enhance our understanding on the long-tern effects of climate change and land use practice on prairie ecosystems in Great Plains in US. The data we collected were assimilated into an ecosystem model and are proven to help identify some source of the uncertainties in model’s projections of ecosystem responses to climate change. The knowledge that we have obtained have the potential to be incorporated in Earth system model for more accurate projections of terrestrial biogeochemistry.

 

Moreover, our findings on the responses of ecosystem functions under long-term climate change and agricultural practice can help research in other disciplines and policy makers to know the consequences of climate change or land use practice. For example, the results can be used to estimate economic or social risks under future climate and land use management. The data we collected can be used by other disciplines, such as Integrated Assessment Models to predict the consequences under different climate and land use scenarios. The technique and on-line tool we developed during this project to assimilate long-term experimental data in ecosystem models can help modelers to improve model’s behavior in the projections of future state of ecosystems or help the policy makers to make the more sustainable policies.

 

In addition, we published more than 50 papers in peer-reviewed journals, gave more than 20 presentations at influential professional meetings, trained many young scientists, including undergraduate students, graduate students and post-doc fellows in field measurements, laboratory analysis, modeling, data processing, and scientific paper writing and presentations.
